utterance: Yes; but I did not tell you that I knew the uses of all things. The St. John's wort was gathered in the country, when I was a boy, by many old people, who believed it to be so useful as a medicine that they dried it and kept some of it always in the house.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And what was it good for ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: It was supposed to cure the ague, and to be good for jaundice, and I think useful for wounds and for internal bleeding, and perhaps for many things besides, for it was a plant of many virtues.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And not all of them true?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: YOU should know the mallow, Cissy, with the pink flowers close at your feet.
speaker: narrator

utterance: But what do you call it ?
speaker: Cissy

utterance: Oh! cheeses.' Yes, I know.
speaker: Cissy

utterance: Cheeses? why do you call it' cheeses'?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Because little cheeses grow all over it, and so we play with them, and call them cheeses.'
speaker: Cissy

utterance: What a sprawling plant ! too lazy to grow straight.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I can't; it sticks so hard.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: But the end of the root is broken off.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: It is almost like liquorice root, but not so nice, is it?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Good to eat?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: But it is not used now-a-days ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: How is it used ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Only the roots ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: The stem is tough like the root, and straggling.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: It seems to be soft and velvety all over.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: That is not so easy. They would be rather rounded if they were not so deeply notched at the edge.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Lobes! what are they?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Never mind what we call them, so long as we know what it is that we mean.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And these plants have lobed leaves.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And there are tiny leaves at the bottom of the foot-stalks upon the stems.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Some are only buds, some are open flowers, and some almost like buds, only that the flowers have opened and fallen off.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And should we always find all these three parts ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: But in the mallow the green leaves of the flower-cup are very large.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I must not forget that.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Yes, the coloured flower-leaves; and there are five, broadest towards the outer end, and notched. Very pretty pink with purple lines.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Do you smell anything ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: No; I don't think they are scented.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Now for the third set of parts in the flower.
speaker: narrator

utterance: And such a lot of stamens ! That's the name.
speaker: Cissy

utterance: More than five ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
I shall not forget. And see how the flowers are twisted round before they open, almost as they are in the bindweed. But the cheeses'
I want to know about them.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Oh yes; there's a little cheese inside.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I eat them sometimes,
speaker: Cissy

utterance: I suppose some people have believed ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: That would be a useful medicine.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Mallows must have been known thousands of years ago.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And are they ever eaten now ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I should not think we could eat them like cabbage.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Any way, if the mallow is a weed it is not quite a useless one.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Do tell me how it was done, uncle.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What was it done for ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: To deck the living and the dead.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: WHAT is the large white flower, uncle, with the stems running all over the hedge ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: The large white flowers like a funnel ?
speaker: Cissy

utterance: And it runs all over the bushes, with a flower here and there.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Do they grow easily ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And why are they sorry?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Is there no other plant which has such roots ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: But what are twiners ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I see the stem wound round and round all these bushes. And do they wind themselves up ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And does it wind as it grows ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Do all twiners move from right to left ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And any others?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I should like to see the tip of the stem moving round and round. How long does it take them to get round ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Then we would have to watch for two hours to see the tip go round once.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I suppose that the quicker they grow the faster they move.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: They are not heart-shaped quite, nor yet flat-iron shape, nor yet three-cornered. I don't know.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What do you say to arrow-shape, or like an arrow-head ?
speaker: narrator

utterance: I have never seen an arrow-head, but I have seen the top end of iron railings almost like it.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: With long stalks.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: When are leaves 'in pairs'?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And these are not opposite, or in pairs, but single. Don't you think bindweed' is a nicer name than 'convolvulus,' uncle ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And one name is English, the other foreign.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Except for little girls,

utterance: I said funnel just now; but I do not like funnel-shaped, because the sides are not straight, but bent inwards.

utterance: More like the end of a trumpet or a Frenchhorn.

utterance: Much more like, but so narrow at the bottom.

utterance: Because they are almost square,

utterance: I shall call them flower-leaves; I shall not think of bracts' when I want to.

utterance: Can we wait and see it open ?

utterance: And I suppose the flowers close again early in the evening ?

utterance: Yes, I did notice it; and when the flowers close they do not fall off readily, but wither and die.

utterance: And see one little thread standing up in the middle, and five others standing around it.

utterance: Yes, uncle ; but I must grow a little bigger before I bother myself about them.

utterance: Yes ; I see it in both the halves.
